sections.title: Introduction
content: Ceylon Cinnamon (Cinnamomum zeylanicum), native to Sri Lanka, is the purest and highest-grade cinnamon globally.
Sri Lanka dominates 90% of the market, renowned for its superior quality, delicate flavor, and health benefits.
Unlike Cassia, Ceylon Cinnamon is low in coumarin, making it safer for regular consumption.

sections.title: Farming Techniques
content: Planting: Spaced 4x3 ft (flat land) or 4x2 ft (slopes), with pits treated with rock phosphate.
Propagation: Seeds (June–July) or semi-hardwood cuttings from high-yield plants.
Pruning: Regular trimming to ensure straight stems for bark harvesting.
Irrigation: Basin/drip systems in dry zones; rainfall-dependent in wet zones.

sections.title: Environmental Requirements
content: Climate: 25–35°C, 75–85% humidity, and 1875+ mm annual rainfall.
Soil: Well-drained acidic red/sandy loam; avoids waterlogged/saline soils.
Altitude: Up to 700m elevation in humid conditions.

sections.title: Disease & Pest Management
content: Diseases: Rough Bark, White Root (treated with tebuconazole, sulfur).
Pests: Pink Stem Borer (insecticides), Thrips (pruning + Abamectin).
Prevention: Soil drainage, selective weeding, and organic compost.

sections.title: Harvesting & Grading
content: Harvest: Bark peeled from 1.5–2-year-old stems during rainy seasons.
Grades: Alba (6mm, premium), Continental, Mexican, Hamburg (thicker quills).
Uses: Bakery, teas, pharmaceuticals, and antioxidants.

sections.title: Tips for Success
content: Use vegetative propagation for uniform quality.
Test soil pH (dolomite adjusts acidity).
Avoid over-pruning; retain 3–5 shoots per bush.
Market value peaks for Alba-grade quills.
